column3: Minimum vertical separation resolvable in a dataset, measured in meters.
The description of a geographical location of dataset collection.
Geographical longitude of a polygon point which represents one vertex of an area of dataset collection.
Geographical latitude of a polygon point which represents one vertex of an area of dataset collection.
The most north latitude of a bounding box representing an area of dataset collection.
The most south latitude of a bounding box representing an area of dataset collection.
The most east longitude of a bounding box representing an area of dataset collection.
The most west longitude of a bounding box representing an area of dataset collection.
Geographic longitude of a point which represents a location of dataset collection.
Geographic latitude of a point which represents a location of dataset collection.
The IRI of the scheme or authority used for the Variable Identifier.
The name of the scheme or authority used for the Variable Identifier.
IRI describing the variable.
Human readable name of variable being recorded in datastream.
The IRI of the scheme or authority used for the Data Source Identifier.
The name of the scheme or authority used for the Data Source Identifier.
IRI describing the data source (e.g., PID of an instrument).
Human readable name of data source from which the variable(s) come(s).
The IRI of the scheme or authority used for the Data Stream Identifier.
The name of the scheme or authority used for the Data Stream Identifier.
Unique identifier of collection of records coming from a data source.
Human readable name of collection of records coming from a data source.
The type of the distributor of the described dataset (organization, or person).
The role of the distributor in bringing the described dataset into existence.
The IRI of the scheme or authority used for the Distributor Affiliation Identifier.
The name of the scheme or authority used for the Distributor Affiliation Identifier.
Globally unique string that identifies the organizational affiliation of the distributor.
The organizational or institutional affiliation of the distributor.
The IRI of the scheme or authority used for the Distributor Identifier.
The name of the scheme or authority used for the Distributor Identifier.
Globally unique string that identifies the distributor (an individual or legal entity).
Date when the dataset was distributed.
Technical statement(s) for querying dataset distribution.
The access protocol configuration for quering dataset distribution.
The protocol used to access the dataset distribution.
Total size of dataset distribution.
A media type, formerly known as a MIME type, of dataset distribution.
The identifier type used to identify the dataset distribution.
A globally unique string that identifies the dataset distribution.
Type of the date with respect to the dataset.
Date relevant to dataset.
The IRI of the scheme or authority used for the Rights Identifier.
The name of the scheme or authority used for the Rights Identifier.
IRI of the license for the dataset being described.
A standardized version of the license name.
An address of the publisher.
The IRI of the scheme or authority used for the Publisher Identifier.
The name of the scheme or authority used for the Publisher Identifier.
Globally unique string that identifies the publisher.
The type of the contributor of the described dataset (organization or person).
The role of the contributor in bringing the described dataset into existence.
The IRI of the scheme or authority used for the Contributor Affiliation Identifier.
The name of the scheme or authority used for the Contributor Affiliation Identifier.
Globally unique string that identifies the organizational affiliation of the contributor.
The organizational or institutional affiliation of the contributor.
The IRI of the scheme or authority used for the Contributor Identifier.
The name of the scheme or authority used for the Contributor Identifier.
Globally unique string that identifies the contributor (an individual or legal entity).
The type of the creator of the described dataset (organization or person).
The role of the creator in bringing the described dataset into existence.
The IRI of the scheme or authority used for the Creator Affiliation Identifier.
The name of the scheme or authority used for the Creator Affiliation Identifier.
Globally unique string that identifies the organizational affiliation of the creator.
The organizational or institutional affiliation of the creator.
The IRI of the scheme or authority used for the Creator Identifier.
The name of the scheme or authority used for the Creator Identifier.
Globally unique string that identifies the creator (an individual or legal entity).
Free text subject, keyword, classification code, or key phrase describing the dataset or purpose for which the dataset can be used.
The IRI of the scheme or authority used for the Subject Concept IRI.
The name of the scheme or authority used for the Subject Concept IRI.
The IRI of a concept (keyword, classification code, or controlled key phrase) that defines the dataset or indicates for which concepts the dataset can be used.
Primary language used to present the dataset (if multiple languages are present). Use a code from IETF BCP 47
The subtype of the identifier used to specify the related resource.
The subtype of the identifier used to specify the dataset being described.
Information about the award funder.
Information about the project award.
Information about the sources of funding that enabled and drove the creation of the dataset. (Non-monetary sources are described under Contributor.)
Information about the temporal coverage and resolution of the dataset being described.
Information about the vertical area (altitude and/or depth) covered by the dataset being described.
Information about a geospatial coverage represented using polygon.
Information about a geospatial coverage represented using bounding box.
Information about a geospatial coverage represented as a single point.
Information about the geospatial area (region on Earth) covered by the dataset being described.
This property is purely used to capture subjects not yet being defined by controlled vocabulary.
Variable being directly measured.
Variable intended being computer or indirectly measured.
This property is purely used to capture variables not yet being defined by controlled vocabulary.
Information about a single entity being measured or computed.

Information about a Data Source, a physical or conceptual entity that creates the data streams that make up the described dataset. The data source may or may not be associated with a fixed location; for example, a series of discrete sensors deployed over time to a single location may be considered a single data source in some systems.
Information about a Data Stream, a collection of one or more variable records originating from a single data source (e.g., sensor, process, or person). A data stream can grow over time.
Information describing the entities that constitute the dataset being described, and their organization and provenance. (The dataset is defined as coming from a single Data Source.)
Information about the distributor affiliations.
Information about the distributor identifier.
Information about the distributor name.
Information about the distributor of this dataset distribution. The Distributor includes persons or legal entities that responsible for distributing the dataset distribution.
Details about the distribution access.

Details about the distribution for this individual public presentation of the dataset (if part of the Distribution metadata), or for all the public presentations of the dataset being described (if part of the Dataset metadata).
Information about relevant dates related to the resource being described. One instance of date must be of datsetDateType=Published.
Information about the license identifier.
Information about ways in which the dataset may or may not be accessed and used.
Information about the publisher identifier.

Information about the entity that plays the principal role in officially making the dataset public. The role can be to hold, archive, publish, print, distribute, release, issue, or produce the dataset being described. This property is often used to formulate the citation, so consider the prominence of the role and of the entity. For datasets, use the primary repository for serving the data, or the primary organization taking responsibility for serving the data, as the Publisher. The Distribution element can be used to describe the entity(ies) that make the dataset accessible.
Information about a contributor's affiliations.
Information about a contributor identifier.
Information about a contributor name.

Information about a Contributor entity that helped bring into existence the dataset being described. Contributors can be people, organizations and/or physical or virtual infrastructure (e.g., sensors, software).
Information about the creator affiliations.
Information about the creator identifier.
Information about the creator name.

Information about the Creator entity that brought into existence the dataset being described. Creators can be people, organizations and/or physical or virtual infrastructure (e.g., sensors, software).
Controlled concepts that define the dataset or purpose.
Concepts (keywords, classification, or free text terms) that define the dataset or purpose (subjects which can be addressed) using the dataset.
Topic information that defines the dataset's subject or purpose.
Detailed information (typically at the level of an abstract) about the dataset being described.
Information about a name or title by which the dataset being described is known.
Information about the language in which the dataset being described is provided.
Information about the version of the resource being described.
Information about resource related to the dataset or other entity being described.
Information about the globally unique and persistent identifier used to identify and optionally access (meta)data of the dataset being described.
Information about the type of the resource being described with metadata.
A person without a specifically defined role in the development of the resource, but who is someone the author wishes to recognize.
A standards-setting body from which Registration Agencies obtain official recognition and guidance.
Institution/organization officially appointed by a Registration Authority to handle specific tasks within a defined area of responsibility.
Person on the membership list of a designated project/project team.
Person officially designated as manager of a project. Project may consist of one or many project teams and sub-teams.
Person who is a Principal Investigator for a project and who should be contacted for further information about the project.
Person who is a Principal Investigator for a project and who is responsible for Data management in the project.
Person officially designated as head of project team or sub- project team instrumental in the work necessary to development of the resource.
Typically a person or organization responsible for the artistry and form of a media product.
Typically, the organization allowing the resource to be available on the internet through the provision of its hardware/software/operating support.
A person who oversees the details related to the publication format of the resource.
Institution tasked with responsibility to generate/disseminate copies of the resource in either electronic or print form.
Person (or organization with a staff of data managers, such as a data centre) responsible for maintaining the finished resource.
Person tasked with reviewing, enhancing, cleaning, or standardizing metadata and the associated data submitted for storage, use, and maintenance within a data centre or repository
Person/institution responsible for finding, gathering/collecting data under the guidelines of the author(s) or Principal Investigator (PI)
Person with knowledge of how to access, troubleshoot, or otherwise field issues related to the resource.
The role of the contributor in bringing the described dataset into existence.
Uncategorized resource.
A structured series of steps which can be executed to produce a final outcome, allowing users a means to specify and enact their work in a more reproducible manner.
A resource consisting primarily of words for reading.
A resource primarily intended to be heard.
A computer program in source code (text) or compiled form. Use this type for all software components supporting scholarly research.
An organized system of apparatus, appliances, staff, etc., for supplying some function(s) required by end users.
An inanimate, three-dimensional object or substance.
An abstract, conceptual, graphical, mathematical or visualization model that represents empirical objects, phenomena, or physical processes.
A resource requiring interaction from the user to be understood, executed, or experienced
A visual representation other than text
A non-persistent, time-based occurrence.

Data stream represent a collection of one or more variable records originating from a single data source (e.g., sensor) which properties remain unchanged during the data stream existence. In some use-cases, the data source location is required to remain unchanged (e.g., sensors attached to a meteorological tower). Data stream can grow over time.
Dataset is a logical grouping of one or more data streams. It is can be provided in various data distributions. Dataset might be part of (parent) data catalog.
A collection of datasets.
A factual and objective publication with a focused intent to identify and describe specific data, sets of data, or data collections to facilitate discoverability.
An aggregation of resources, which may encompass collections of one resourceType as well as those of mixed types. A collection is described as a group; its parts may also be separately described.
A series of visual representations imparting an impression of motion when shown in succession. May or may not include sound.
This is a set of controlled terms from DataCite/DCMI for the category of resource being described.
IRI of the schema for the funder identifier.
Name of the schema for the funderIdentifier.
Globally unique string that identifies the funding provider.
Name of the organization providing the funding for the described dataset ('funding provider').
The code assigned by the funding provider to a sponsored award (grant). (Can be an IRI, but typically is not.)
The IRI leading to a page provided by the funder for more information about the award (grant).
The human readable title of the award, grant, or other specific funding mechanism for the described dataset.
The total duration of data temporal coverage.
Interval between two consecutive data records.
The end date of the data.
The start date of the data.
The unique identifier of the Datum (reference frame) used for the Vertical Extent values.
The name of the Datum (reference frame) used for the Vertical Extent values.
The IRI of the scheme or authority used for the Vertical Extent Unit Identifier.
The name of the scheme or authority used for the Vertical Extent Unit Identifier.
The IRI for the unit used to specify Vertical Extent.
Unit used to specify Vertical Extent.
A minimum vertical extent of dataset collection. In case of depth, this represents a maximum depth of dataset collection.
A maximum vertical extent of dataset collection. In case of depth, this represents a minimum depth of dataset collection.
The Internationalized Resource Identifier (IRI) is an internet protocol standard which builds on the Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) protocol by greatly expanding the set of permitted characters.
Permanent identifier for Web applications. Mostly used to publish vocabularies and ontologies. The letters ‘w3’ stand for “World Wide Web”.

Uniform Resource Name; is a unique and persistent identifier of an electronic document. The syntax is: urn:< NID>:<NSS> The leading urn: sequence is case-insensitive, <NID> is the namespace identifier, <NSS> is the namespace-specific string.
Uniform Resource Locator, also known as web address, is a specific character string that constitutes a reference to a resource. The syntax is: schema://domain:port/path?qu ery_string#fragment_id

Uniform Resource Identifier is a string that provides a unique address (either on the Internet or on another private network, such as a computer filesystem or an Intranet) representing a resource, and implicitly describes where a resource can be found. A resource identification need not suggest the retrieval of resource representations over the Internet, nor need they imply network-based resources at all.
Universal Product Code is a barcode symbology used for tracking trade items in stores. Its most common form, the UPC-A, consists of 12 numerical digits.
Persistent Uniform Resource Locator. A PURL is an IRI, and therefore has three parts: (1) a protocol, (2) a resolver address, and (3) a name.
PubMed identifier; a unique number assigned to each PubMed record.
Life Science Identifiers; a unique identifier for data in the Life Science domain. Format: urn:lsid:authority:namespace:id entifier:revision
The linking ISSN or ISSN-L enables collocation or linking among different media versions of a continuing resource.
International Standard Text Code; a unique “number” assigned to a textual work. An ISTC consists of 16 numbers and/or letters.
International Standard Serial Number; a unique 8-digit number used to identify a print or electronic periodical publication.
International Standard Book Number; a unique numeric book identifier. There are 2 formats: a 10-digit ISBN format and a 13- digit ISBN.
International Geo Sample Number; a 9-digit alphanumeric code that uniquely identifies samples from our natural environment and related sampling features.
A handle is an abstract reference to a resource.
Electronic International Standard Serial Number; ISSN used to identify periodicals in electronic form (eISSN or e- ISSN).

European Article Number, now renamed International Article Number, but retaining the original acronym, is a 13-digit barcoding standard which is a superset of the original 12-digit Universal Product Code (UPC) system.
Digital Object Identifier; a character string used to uniquely identify an object. A DOI name is divided into two parts, a prefix and a suffix, separated by a slash.

Astrophysics Data System bibliographic codes; a standardized 19 character identifier according to the syntax yyyyjjjjjvvvvmppppa. See http://info- uri.info/registry/OAIHandler?ve rb=GetRecord&metadataPrefix= reg&identifier=info:bibcode/

arXiv identifier; arXiv.org is a repository of preprints of scientific papers in the fields of mathematics, physics, astronomy, computer science, quantitative biology, statistics, and quantitative finance.

Archival Resource Key; URL designed to support long-term access to information objects. In general, ARK syntax is of the form (brackets indicate [optional] elements: [http://NMA/]ark:/NAAN/Name [Qualifier]
The type of internet identifier used for the resource. Note many of these identifier types are *not* IRIs.
The date the resource is removed.
The date or date range during which the dataset or resource is accurate.
The date of the last update to the resource, when the resource is being added to. May be a range.
The date the creator submits the resource to the publisher. This could be different from Accepted if the publisher then applies a selection process.
The date that the resource is published or distributed e.g. to a data centre

The date the resource itself was put together; this could refer to a timeframe in ancient history, be a date range or a single date for a final component, e.g. the finalised file with all of the data.
The date or date range in which the resource content was collected.
The specific, documented date at which the resource receives a copyrighted status, if applicable.
The date the resource is made publicly available. May be a range.
The date that the publisher accepted the resource into their system.
The date when dataset was first time made publicaly available.
The type( or role) of the date being provided.

Any person or institution making a significant contribution to the development and/or maintenance of the resource, but whose contribution does not “fit” other controlled vocabulary for contributorType.

A Work Package is a recognized data product, not all of which is included in publication. The package, instead, may include notes, discarded documents, etc. The Work Package Leader is responsible for ensuring the comprehensive contents, versioning, and availability of the Work Package during the development of the resource.
Designated administrator over one or more groups/teams working to produce a resource or over one or more steps of a development process.
Person or organization that issued a contract or under the auspices of which a work has been written, printed, published, developed, etc.
Person or institution owning or managing property rights, including intellectual property rights over the resource.
Typically refers to a group of individuals with a lab, department, or division; the group has a particular, defined focus of activity.

A person involved in analyzing data or the results of an experiment or formal study. May indicate an intern or assistant to one of the authors who helped with research but who was not so “key” as to be listed as an author.
Information about the license identifier.

ISNI (International Standard Name Identifier) is an ISO standard, in use by numerous libraries, publishers, databases, and rights management organizations around the world. It is used to uniquely identify persons and organizations involved in creative activities, as well as public personas of both, such as pseudonyms, stage names, record labels or publishing imprints.

GRID (Global Research Identifier Database) is a free and openly available global database of research-related organisations, cataloging research-related organisations and providing each with a unique and persistent identifier.
ROR is the Research Organization Registry, a community-led project to develop an open, sustainable, usable, and unique identifier for every research organization in the world.
The LinkedIn ID is a permanent number assigned to person's LinkedIn profile.
ResearcherID is an identifying system for scientific authors.
The Scopus author identifier distinguishes authors among themselves by assigning a unique number to each author.
The ORCID (Open Researcher and Contributor ID) is a nonproprietary alphanumeric code to uniquely identify scientific and other academic authors and contributors.
Identifier scheme used for identifying person, organization, system, physical or digital object.
An organization is an entity - such as a company, an institution, or an association - comprising one or more people and having a particular purpose.

A person (plural people or persons) is a being that has certain capacities or attributes such as reason, morality, consciousness or self-consciousness, and being a part of a culturally established form of social relations such as kinship, ownership of property, or legal responsibility.
Types of creator responsiple for the ressource creation.
MIME type of the digital object
The Software Package Data Exchange (SPDX), an open standard for communicating software bill of material information, including components, licenses, copyrights, and security references.
Identifier scheme used for defining licenses.
